Question: Which word is the name of a vector quantity?
What is the size of the resultant of the two forces shown in the diagram?
What is the correct unit for the quantity shown?

A length of copper pipe, of uniform cross-section and several metres long, carries water to a tap. /n Measurements are taken to determine accurately the volume of copper in the pipe. /n Which instruments are used?
Part of a speed–time graph for two runners is shown. /n They are running along the same track. /n Which statement must be correct?

Options.A: Both runners started at the same moment.
Options.B: Runner 1 has a greater acceleration than runner 2.
Options.C: Runner 1 is moving faster than runner 2.
Options.D: The distance between the two runners stays constant.

Question: The graph shows how the speed of a car varies with time. /n Which statement about the acceleration of the car between the times 10 s and 20 s is correct?

Options.C: The acceleration is constant, but not zero.

Question: In which descent is the acceleration equal to the acceleration of free fall g at all times?

Options.A: a bungee jumper leaping from a bridge
Options.B: a feather falling in a vertical tube that contains a vacuum
Options.C: a hailstone travelling to Earth at terminal velocity
Options.D: a sky-diver dropping from an aircraft towards the ground

Question: A body slides down a frictionless slope, as shown. /n As the body presses on the surface, the surface pushes back on the body. /n In which direction does the surface push back on the body?
The Earth travels at constant speed in a circular orbit around the Sun. /n Which arrows show the direction of the acceleration of the Earth and the direction of the velocity of the Earth?
A student balances a non-uniform object on a pivot. /n To do this, a weight is suspended near the left-hand end of the object, as shown. /n Where is the centre of mass of the object?

A load L is suspended from two springs that are in parallel. /n The extension of each spring is x. /n The springs are then arranged to hang vertically, one below the other. /n In this new arrangement, what is the total extension of the two springs?
The diagram shows three tubes P, Q and R. /n Each tube contains air trapped by a water column. /n Which statement is correct?

Options.A: The pressure of the trapped air is equal in tubes P, Q and R.
Options.B: The pressure of the trapped air is greatest in tube Q.
Options.C: The pressure of the trapped air is greatest in tube R.
Options.D: The pressure of the trapped air is greatest in tube P.

Question: Which graph shows the relationship between the pressure and the volume of a fixed mass of gas at constant temperature?
An object X has mass m and velocity v. /n A second object Y has mass 2m and velocity 2v. /n What is the value of the ratio of kinetic energy of X to kinetic energy of Y?
Where is energy released by the fusion of hydrogen nuclei to form helium?

Options.B: in a radioactive isotope emitting alpha-particles
Options.C: in the core of the Earth
Options.D: in the core of the Sun

Question: A student uses a newton meter to pull an object a distance d horizontally along a flat surface in a time of t. /n The newton meter reading is F. /n What is given by the expression (F × d) / t?

A student is given a thermometer that reads 1 °C in pure melting ice and 101 °C in pure boiling water. /n She uses it to measure the temperature of some water before and after it is heated. /n How does the rise in temperature of the water calculated from her results compare with the correct value?

A student makes four statements about evaporation and boiling. /n 1 Both involve an increase in molecular separation. /n 2 Both occur only at a fixed temperature. /n 3 Both involve the absorption of thermal energy. /n 4 Both occur throughout the liquid. /n Which two statements are correct?
How is specific latent heat defined?

Options.A: the heat absorbed or emitted by unit mass during a change of a state without a temperature change
Options.B: the heat absorbed or emitted by unit mass during unit temperature change
Options.C: the heat absorbed or emitted during a change of a state without a temperature change
Options.D: the heat absorbed or emitted during unit temperature change

Question: A syringe containing air is sealed at one end. /n The piston is free to move. /n The air is heated. /n What happens to the average distance between air molecules and the density of the air?

Options.D: stays the same stays the same

Question: A metal disc is heated to 600 °C and then lowered into a beaker of water. /n What happens to the mass of the metal disc and to the mass of the water in the beaker? /n mass of metal disc /n mass of water in beaker
Which description defines the amplitude of a water wave in a ripple tank?

Options.A: half of the vertical distance between a trough and a peak
Options.B: the horizontal distance between adjacent peaks
Options.C: the horizontal distance between a trough and an adjacent peak
Options.D: the vertical distance between a trough and a peak

Question: Here are four statements about wavefronts. /n 1 Wavefronts from a point source are straight lines. /n 2 Wavefronts from a point source are circular. /n 3 Wavefronts are parallel to the direction of energy movement. /n 4 Wavefronts are perpendicular to the direction of energy movement. /n Which two statements are correct?
An object O is placed in front of a plane mirror. /n I is the image formed. /n A ray from the top of the object is incident on the mirror at X. /n What happens to this ray?

Options.A: It reflects and passes through the bottom of O.
Options.B: It reflects and passes through the top of O.
Options.C: It reflects as though it came from the bottom of I.
Options.D: It reflects as though it came from the top of I.

Question: The diagram shows light passing from glass into air. /n What is the name of angle P?
An object is placed in front of a converging lens of focal length 4.0 cm. /n The height of the image is 6.0 cm. /n What is the linear magnification produced by the lens?
Which row shows the speed of sound in air (ca), liquid (cL) and solid (cs) in order from slowest to fastest?

A man stands 80 m in front of a cliff face. /n He makes a loud bang and listens for the echo. /n He makes a loud bang once every second. /n He hears an echo exactly halfway between the bang that caused it and the next bang. /n What is the speed of sound?
The diagram shows two magnetic field lines of the magnetic field around two bar magnets. /n P Q /n Which row shows the magnetic poles at end P and end Q of the two magnets?

A metal plate X is attached to earth by a battery. /n The plate has a positive charge. /n A second metal plate Y is initially uncharged and connected to earth. /n This plate is positioned parallel to X. /n What happens as Y is brought closer to X?

Options.A: Electrons flow from Y to earth only.
Options.B: Electrons flow to Y from earth only.
Options.C: Protons flow from Y to earth and electrons flow to Y from earth.
Options.D: Protons flow to Y from earth and electrons flow from Y to earth.

Question: The diagram shows a metal lightning conductor attached to a building. /n Why is the lightning conductor made of copper?

Options.A: Both positive and negative charges can flow through copper.
Options.C: So the lightning conductor has a low electrical resistance.
Options.D: So the heat is conducted away quickly.

Question: Which symbol does not represent a power source?
Resistors of different resistances are connected to a power supply in either a parallel circuit or a series circuit. /n Which statement is correct?

Options.A: The current is the same in all resistors connected in parallel.
Options.B: The current is the same in all resistors connected in series.
Options.C: The voltage across each resistor is different for all resistors connected in parallel.
Options.D: The voltage across each resistor is the same for all resistors connected in series.

Question: An ammeter is connected to three resistors and a power supply. /n Which arrangement of resistors gives the greatest ammeter reading?

A hotplate on an electric cooker contains two identical resistors. /n The switch has three positions. /n position 1 The two resistors are connected in series to the mains supply. /n position 2 The two resistors are connected in parallel to the mains supply. /n position 3 Just one resistor is connected to the mains supply. /n Which positions correspond to the low, the medium and the high power settings? /n low power medium power high power

A mains electric circuit is fitted with a circuit breaker rather than a fuse. /n Where is the circuit breaker connected and what happens when the current is too large? /n A circuit breaker is connected in /n When the current is too large

Options.A: the live wire. a thin wire melts and breaks the circuit.
Options.B: the live wire. an electromagnet opens a switch.
Options.C: the neutral wire. a thin wire melts and breaks the circuit.
Options.D: the neutral wire. an electromagnet opens a switch.

Question: Transformers are used to transmit electrical energy between power stations and transmission cables, as shown. /n What is the purpose of the transformer in the diagram?

Options.A: to decrease the current and the potential difference from the power station
Options.B: to decrease the current and increase the potential difference from the power station
Options.C: to increase the current and the potential difference from the power station
Options.D: to increase the current and decrease the potential difference from the power station

Question: A thermistor warms up as the current in it increases. /n Which graph shows how the voltage V across the thermistor changes as the current I through it is increased?

Radioactive substances are used as tracers in medical examinations. /n A liquid tracer is injected into a patient. /n A detector 20 cm above the patient shows where the radioactive substance is in the body. /n What is the best radioactive substance to use?

Options.A: an alpha-particle emitter with a half-life of a few hours
Options.B: an alpha-particle emitter with a half-life of a few years
Options.C: a gamma ray emitter with a half-life of a few hours
Options.D: a gamma ray emitter with a half-life of a few years

Question: An isotope of lead, Pb 212 82 , is radioactive. /n After three decays, two beta-particles and an alpha-particle have been emitted. /n Another radioactive isotope of lead is formed. /n What is the mass number (nucleon number) of the new isotope of lead?
